text:
‘And here I am again, doing the same thing,’ Raskolnikov said, feeling a bit uneasy and surprised by the old woman’s distrust. ‘Maybe she always acts like this, but I didn’t notice it before,’ he thought, feeling uncomfortable.

The old woman paused for a moment, then stepped aside and pointed to the door of the room, saying, ‘Please come in, sir.’

The small room Raskolnikov entered had yellow paper on the walls, geraniums, and muslin curtains at the windows. It was brightly lit by the setting sun. 

‘So the sun shines like this too!’ Raskolnikov thought quickly, trying to take in everything in the room so he could remember it. But there was nothing special in the room. The old furniture was all yellow wood and included a sofa with a big curved back, an oval table in front of it, a dressing table with a mirror between the windows, chairs against the walls, and a few cheap prints in yellow frames showing German girls with birds. In the corner, a light was burning in front of a small icon. Everything was very clean; the floor and furniture were shiny and polished. 

‘Lizaveta must have cleaned,’ the young man thought. There was not a speck of dust anywhere in the flat.

**PAGE SUMMARY:** Raskolnikov visits an old woman to pawn something, feeling uneasy about her mistrust and observing the cleanliness of her modest flat.
